author: Philip Baker
title: ASX: Are we at the end of the wild roller-coaster ride?
text:
We're not quite at capitulation of the ASX ... yet Share on twitter by Philip Baker When everyone turns overwhelmingly gloomy and there's talk of the C-word, it sends a signal to the value managers that we're getting close to the end of this wild ride in the sharemarket.
But we're probably not there just yet.
Capitulation.
That's the word that's what fund managers are looking for â€“ that panic selling from investors worried they won't get any of their capital back and almost relieved to finally book the loss they've seen building for a months.
For an army of self-managed super funds, the investment game has looked like a piece of cake for the past three years: buy those bank shares for the dividends and watch the price go up as well.
But now they are being tested, how will they react?
Buying shares has quickly become a nail-biting exercise as people struggle to come to grips with a changed and threatening environment.
September and October are known as the witching months and although the peak of the market was reached in April, investors are probably yet to see final sell-off in the stockmarket which will signal the final capitulation of investors. Then, so the theory goes, the stockmarket will proceed to climb its wall of worry. And the wall includes
 Some people are still wondering whether to sell, when investment theory says they now should be starting to ask when is it the time to buy?
That's why the first sell is the best one, but it can also be hard to pull the trigger. (Taking a smaller loss now rather than a bigger one later is the theory). Real capitulation involves an extremely busy day with huge amounts of shares trading hands and very sharp declines in prices. The volumes on Thursday weren't as large as they were last week when the major S&P ASX200 index was closer to 5000 .
Still, the major index fell 2 per cent on Thursday after gaining more than 2 per cent in the previous session, a rare combination. Indeed 2 per cent days in whatever direction are rare but two consecutive sessions with a 2 handle, and in the opposite direction are unusual.
All up, the index has fallen about 15 per cent from its recent peak so it's not yet in bear-market territory, as defined by a 20 per cent fall.
If there is something that stands out during this week's wild ride in the sharemarket it is this: widespread nervousness and uncertainty means these dizzying swings in sentiment will continue to menace markets.
And when equity markets take a tumble, even the good companies often get caught up in the melee. But that's a chance to add to the portfolio.
Some analysts have compared the sell-off to the Asian and emerging markets crisis in 1997 and 1998. The local sharemarket fell 10-23 per cent in those years but managed to recover both times.
The thing about emerging markets is you can get them very right or very wrong.
The more bears that come out of hibernation and hog the headlines, the closer investors will get to capitulation.
A few more dire warnings, like the one from Citigroup chief economist Willem Buiter who reckons there is a 55 per cent chance of a global recession in the next two years, should do the trick.
Mr Buiter thinks a recession will force central banks in the United States, Japan and Europe to beef up their monetary stimulus.
But that's a problem in itself. One of the main reasons markets are so skittish now is the fear that what central banks have done since the crisis hasn't really worked. The Federal Reserve wants to hike rates but there is so much debate about how the world will cope. If the globe can't cope with a quarter of a percentage point rate rise from zero, where rates have been since 2008, then maybe investors have a right to be nervous.
